turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: We'll hear argument now on number oh one four hundred, Ricky Bell versus Gary Bradford Cone.
Mr. M- Mr. Moore.

turn.speaker: michael_e_moore
turn.label: Mr. Michael E. Moore
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court The court of appeals was without authority to grant habeas relief under twenty-eight USC twenty-two fifty-four D one on respondent's ineffective assistance of counsel claim for two reasons: first, because the State court decision rejecting the claim correctly identified this Court's decision in Strickland versus Washington as the clearly established Federal law governing this case, not United States versus Cronic as respondent contends, and second, because the State court's application of Strickland to the facts of respondent's case was not objectively unreasonable.

Turning to the first point, respondent's ineffective assistance claim from the outset of this case has asserted two specific errors that his attorney allegedly committed during the sentencing phase of his capital trial first, counsel's alleged failure to present available mitigating evidence and second, his counsel's decision to waive closing argument.
This Court held in Strickland that such claims are properly analyzed under the two part actual deficient performance slash actual prejudice test announced in that case itself.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Mr. Moore, I think what happened in this sentencing proceeding, if I remember correctly, is that the attorney made some remarks at the beginning of the sentencing hearing?

turn.speaker: michael_e_moore
turn.label: Mr. Michael E. Moore
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

He delivered an opening statement, during which he specifically called the jury's attention, as he is permitted to do under Tennessee State law, to guilt phase evidence, mental health evidence, upon which he was relying in mitigation.
He explained to the jury its mitigating significance by relating that evidence specifically to three statutory mitigating factors.
In addition, during that opening statement, he emphasized his client's remorse for his role in the crimes.
He emphasized his client's honorable service for his...

turn.speaker: michael_e_moore
turn.label: Mr. Michael E. Moore
turn.text: country.
Did he...

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: explain that he wouldn't be presenting any evidence or saying anything more?

turn.speaker: michael_e_moore
turn.label: Mr. Michael E. Moore
turn.text: He He did not indicate one way or the other in that statement,

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: but he specifically...

turn.speaker: michael_e_moore
turn.label: Mr. Michael E. Moore
turn.text: [Inaudible]

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Now, would you be here would you still be here if he had not said anything at the opening? Then what rule applies? Suppose the defense attorney just totally remained silent in the sentencing phase.

turn.speaker: michael_e_moore
turn.label: Mr. Michael E. Moore
turn.text: No, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: It is our...

turn.speaker: michael_e_moore
turn.label: Mr. Michael E. Moore
turn.text: It is our position that if the claim focuses on counsel's conduct during the trial and it is not alleged that any errors or omissions he made were the result of State interru- interference or so called surrounding circumstances, then such a claim is properly analyzed under Strickland's two part test.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: the err- the attorney here did successfully object to the presentation of some evidence during the sentencing phase,

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: didn't he?

turn.speaker: michael_e_moore
turn.label: Mr. Michael E. Moore
turn.text: indeed, Your Honor, he did.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: In addition,

turn.speaker: michael_e_moore
turn.label: Mr. Michael E. Moore
turn.text: he he objected to some hearsay evidence.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: J- just to go back to Justice O'Connor's question, suppose the attorney says nothing and la- later says, y- you know, I was just I don't know stressed out, traumatized.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: No, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: michael_e_moore
turn.label: Mr. Michael E. Moore
turn.text: N- No, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: When does Cronic apply?

turn.speaker: michael_e_moore
turn.label: Mr. Michael E. Moore
turn.text: Cronic in our view is properly read to apply only when surrounding circumstances or State interference renders it unlikely that any lawyer could have re- rendered effective assistance of counsel.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Well, in my hy- in my hypothetical, I said he he said I just blanked out for a minute.

turn.speaker: michael_e_moore
turn.label: Mr. Michael E. Moore
turn.text: But th- that circumstance is the the lawyer's own problem.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: ascertain whether that error preju-

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: given in this case that the attorney did provide that there was ineffective assistance at sentencing? Do we take that as a a gi-

turn.speaker: michael_e_moore
turn.label: Mr. Michael E. Moore
turn.text: No your honor No, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: This is not the first time in one of these cases I've been surprised at how skimpy the presentation is at by the defense counsel on sentencing.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, Your Hon-

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: tempted to ask you if i- if this is usual, but th- th- that that's probably not a fair question is it there're so many differences in so many cases.

turn.speaker: michael_e_moore
turn.label: Mr. Michael E. Moore
turn.text: That's correct, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: counsel when...

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: Moore, may I ask you? On that on that branch of it, it seems to me that there was, the prosecutor's presentation to the jury was about a match for the defense attorney's.

turn.speaker: michael_e_moore
turn.label: Mr. Michael E. Moore
turn.text: Y- Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: But I had another question that I wanted to ask you, and that was you presented two questions.

turn.speaker: michael_e_moore
turn.label: Mr. Michael E. Moore
turn.text: Yes, Your...

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: As a matter and and the Sixth Circuit proceeded just the other way.

turn.speaker: michael_e_moore
turn.label: Mr. Michael E. Moore
turn.text: Well, it's our it's our position, Your Honor, that it is not the function of this Court under twenty-two fifty-four D to reach to actually address the merits a- as if it were deciding this claim de novo.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Don't you think it'd be a little coy for us to decide, well, it wasn't an unreasonable application of of Federal law when we, in fact, know or believe that it was a correct application of Federal law? Do you insist that we simply say and go no further than to say, oh, it was it was not an unreasonable er application?

turn.speaker: michael_e_moore
turn.label: Mr. Michael E. Moore
turn.text: I I certainly would not b- begrudge the Court's agreeing that the State court had indeed correctly applied Strickland.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: ascertaining...

turn.speaker: michael_e_moore
turn.label: Mr. Michael E. Moore
turn.text: whether it is reasonable.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Indeed, if we could go no further than than the coy statement that it was not an unreasonable application, I suppose you shouldn't've had two questions.

turn.speaker: michael_e_moore
turn.label: Mr. Michael E. Moore
turn.text: That's correct, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: argument...

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: le- let me interrupt you.

turn.speaker: michael_e_moore
turn.label: Mr. Michael E. Moore
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Thank you.

turn.speaker: michael_e_moore
turn.label: Mr. Michael E. Moore
turn.text: And so, i- i- in- indeed, counsel could've reasonably believed that all of the points he had made during his opening statement, his plea for mercy, his emphasis on his client's remorse, and the mitigating significance of the guilt phase evidence, were fresh in the jury's mind when the jury retired to deliberate because...

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: that...

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: what did he say about the Bronze Star?

turn.speaker: michael_e_moore
turn.label: Mr. Michael E. Moore
turn.text: During his opening statement, he did not specifically mention the Bronze Star because that evidence was not elicited until the his cross examination of one of the witnesses during the sentencing phase.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: So, your answer is he didn't mention it in his argument.

turn.speaker: michael_e_moore
turn.label: Mr. Michael E. Moore
turn.text: He did not mention the Bronze Star.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: But am I right that such evidence was introduced in the Federal court?

turn.speaker: michael_e_moore
turn.label: Mr. Michael E. Moore
turn.text: No, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: none of that evidence...

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: that such evidence was available made in the Federal proceeding?

turn.speaker: michael_e_moore
turn.label: Mr. Michael E. Moore
turn.text: The allegation that it was available was made in the Federal proceeding, but there was no...

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: And was that...

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: allegation denied?

turn.speaker: michael_e_moore
turn.label: Mr. Michael E. Moore
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Yeah.

turn.speaker: michael_e_moore
turn.label: Mr. Michael E. Moore
turn.text: Well, I don't know that it was denied.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: on...

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: but if we're not deciding the case on the basis of what that evidence would prove or disprove, but rather on whether counsel was deficient in failing to introduce it, should we not assume the evidence exists?

turn.speaker: michael_e_moore
turn.label: Mr. Michael E. Moore
turn.text: No, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: We should not?

turn.speaker: michael_e_moore
turn.label: Mr. Michael E. Moore
turn.text: No, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: If If...

turn.speaker: michael_e_moore
turn.label: Mr. Michael E. Moore
turn.text: b- b- because the burden rests with the petitioner, the habeas petitioner, to demonstrate its existence.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: What what was the bas- what was the case you just cited to us for that proposition?

turn.speaker: michael_e_moore
turn.label: Mr. Michael E. Moore
turn.text: Burger versus Kemp.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Mr. Moore, er are you done with that point? I...

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: I- It isn't stated in your brief, but I assume that it's it's it's the Tennessee rule that if if the defense doesn't make a closing a closing statement, the prosecution doesn't either.

turn.speaker: michael_e_moore
turn.label: Mr. Michael E. Moore
turn.text: That's right, and that was the...

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: s- s-

turn.speaker: michael_e_moore
turn.label: Mr. Michael E. Moore
turn.text: the State court found, based on the...

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: evidence...

turn.speaker: michael_e_moore
turn.label: Mr. Michael E. Moore
turn.text: presented to it during the post conviction hearing that counsel made a tactical decision to waive in in order to prevent the senior prosecutor from delivering what he...

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: The fearsome Mr. Strother.

turn.speaker: michael_e_moore
turn.label: Mr. Michael E. Moore
turn.text: I am not I am not acquainted with General Strother, so I'm not...

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: sure, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: gather that this isn't the only occasion on which defense counsel have esch- eschewed the making of closing argument for fear that Mr. Strother would be enabled to unleash his his weaponry.

turn.speaker: michael_e_moore
turn.label: Mr. Michael E. Moore
turn.text: That's correct, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: Can we go back to the Bronze Star? It certainly did come out in the sentencing phase.

turn.speaker: michael_e_moore
turn.label: Mr. Michael E. Moore
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: Do we have any evidence to indicate whether Mr. Dice would have put on evidence showing the Bronze Star if he had not been able to bring it out in cross examination?

turn.speaker: michael_e_moore
turn.label: Mr. Michael E. Moore
turn.text: The record simply doesn't reflect whether or not that would've been the case.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Do you think he was entitled to be pleased with himself for the way he got that in the record?

turn.speaker: michael_e_moore
turn.label: Mr. Michael E. Moore
turn.text: Your Honor, I th-

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: That is that the way you would have done it if you'd been the lawyer?

turn.speaker: michael_e_moore
turn.label: Mr. Michael E. Moore
turn.text: I'm not certain that I that th- hearsay evidence in a prison record is the best evidence of that fact.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: that's all the jury found out about it, too.

turn.speaker: michael_e_moore
turn.label: Mr. Michael E. Moore
turn.text: That's correct, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: th- And we know nothing more about it now? Nothing came out in the Tennessee proceedings...

turn.speaker: michael_e_moore
turn.label: Mr. Michael E. Moore
turn.text: No, Your Honor,

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: and r- and and r-

turn.speaker: michael_e_moore
turn.label: Mr. Michael E. Moore
turn.text: respondent introduced no evidence before the State courts concerning why th- the the Bronze Star was awarded, anything about the circumstances of its award.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: Was it were there any problems in his service record? He served in Germany and Vietnam.

turn.speaker: michael_e_moore
turn.label: Mr. Michael E. Moore
turn.text: Not so insofar as this record reflects, Your Honor, no.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: And did the lawyer put in any evidence about his what kind of a person he was before he went to Vietnam?

turn.speaker: michael_e_moore
turn.label: Mr. Michael E. Moore
turn.text: During sentencing? No.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Thank you, Mr. Moore.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Blatt, we'll hear from you.

turn.speaker: lisa_s_blatt
turn.label: Ms. Lisa S. Blatt
turn.text: [NS] Thank you, Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court The United States has addressed the second question presented, which is whether a defendant must show prejudice to establish a claim of ineffective assistance.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: [Inaudible]

turn.speaker: lisa_s_blatt
turn.label: Ms. Lisa S. Blatt
turn.text: to assume then that the performance was deficient and then address the prejudice prong? No.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: don't get to question two at all, then.

turn.speaker: lisa_s_blatt
turn.label: Ms. Lisa S. Blatt
turn.text: You get to you can ge- you get to question two if, in determining that Strickland and not Cronic is the clearly established law, this Court holds that Cronic does not apply when the claim is an actual ineffective assistance claim.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: What what if the defense counsel presented nothing at all at the sentencing phase, do you think that there is potential for application of Cronic in those circumstances?

turn.speaker: lisa_s_blatt
turn.label: Ms. Lisa S. Blatt
turn.text: Yes, Justice O'Connor.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: in that re-

turn.speaker: lisa_s_blatt
turn.label: Ms. Lisa S. Blatt
turn.text: We do but our difference is very narrow.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Why divide trial into, you know, the one phase and then the the mitigation phase? It's all part of the same trial.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: and say...

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: counsel utterly failed to to litigate this particular piece.

turn.speaker: lisa_s_blatt
turn.label: Ms. Lisa S. Blatt
turn.text: Okay, and We couldn't agree with you more.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Well, what justification do you have for for separating out the mitigation phase from the other, especially when some of the evidence that went to mitigation was presented during during the direct phase?

turn.speaker: lisa_s_blatt
turn.label: Ms. Lisa S. Blatt
turn.text: Right.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: you're giving up the principle.

turn.speaker: lisa_s_blatt
turn.label: Ms. Lisa S. Blatt
turn.text: We don't think...

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: so, what...

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: it just be th- th- here's a counsel who litigated the case properly but he made he made a mistake in in in his litigation? He didn't put on any evidence in the in the mitigation phase.

turn.speaker: lisa_s_blatt
turn.label: Ms. Lisa S. Blatt
turn.text: We don't think so.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: be the result of any...

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: when you say the entire trial, are you talking about the penalty phase or the whole ca- the whole trial?

turn.speaker: lisa_s_blatt
turn.label: Ms. Lisa S. Blatt
turn.text: We would be talking about a penalty phase although I agree with Justice Scalia that in the unique situation of this case, where there's an express procedure that allows the jury to consider the mitigation evidence, it's critical to look at counsel's performance during the g- the guilt phase of the trial.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Counsel...

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: me.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: the...

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: penalty phase?

turn.speaker: lisa_s_blatt
turn.label: Ms. Lisa S. Blatt
turn.text: No, I don't think that is unique and I I'm sorry I...

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: I misspoke. I think it's...

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Which means the two phases are linked.

turn.speaker: lisa_s_blatt
turn.label: Ms. Lisa S. Blatt
turn.text: Right, and if you d- if we're just talking if you take it out of the capital proceeding so you don't have the split trial, all we're saying is if there's an entire failure, we would think that it would be appropriate to presume prejudice.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: Why isn't the line is it know, that you can draw a line one place doesn't mean it's sensible to draw it every place.

turn.speaker: lisa_s_blatt
turn.label: Ms. Lisa S. Blatt
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: So,

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: w- one can say yes I see these are two parts it doesn't follow from that that I have to then separate every examination and every cross examination It's a question of where you draw the line.

turn.speaker: lisa_s_blatt
turn.label: Ms. Lisa S. Blatt
turn.text: Well, I think that's correct, and however you draw the line, this case falls on the Strickland side of the line because this is not a case where counsel didn't do anything.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: May I ask? Supposing you had a case and I know this is not quite it in which there is strong evidence that counsel was mentally disabled and that that made him less effective throughout the entire sentencing hearing.

turn.speaker: lisa_s_blatt
turn.label: Ms. Lisa S. Blatt
turn.text: It would be under Strickland.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Even if...

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: there was severe mental illness on the part of counsel?

turn.speaker: lisa_s_blatt
turn.label: Ms. Lisa S. Blatt
turn.text: Is counsel's j- things that would go to impair counsel judgments or generally irrelevant unless they manifest themself manifest themselves in objectively unreasonable conduct.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: because...

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: treat the failure to make a closing statement or the failure to put in any evidence whatsoever e- e- exactly as if he were a fully qualified lawyer in such a case.

turn.speaker: lisa_s_blatt
turn.label: Ms. Lisa S. Blatt
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: presumption of prejudice.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Burger versus Kemp if the district court in this case had wanted to inquire about the availability of other evidence, it was precluded from doing so because it hadn't been introduced in the State collateral proceedings?

turn.speaker: lisa_s_blatt
turn.label: Ms. Lisa S. Blatt
turn.text: ye- The district court ruled that that that those claims were procedurally barred under an adequate and independent State procedure.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: proceedings...

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: procedural bar rule if the evidence is not adduced at the State collateral proceeding, as opposed to Federal deference?

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: It was a procedural...

turn.speaker: lisa_s_blatt
turn.label: Ms. Lisa S. Blatt
turn.text: In this context, the claims were not made until subsequent post conviction State court proceedings.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: barred.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: was just the failure to adduce the to to make the claim rather than to elicit the evidence?

turn.speaker: lisa_s_blatt
turn.label: Ms. Lisa S. Blatt
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Thank you, Ms. Blatt.

turn.speaker: robert_l_hutton
turn.label: Mr. Robert L. Hutton
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court The main problem in this case is not specific attorney errors.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Well, he did say something initially, did he not, at the sentencing phase?

turn.speaker: robert_l_hutton
turn.label: Mr. Robert L. Hutton
turn.text: Justice O'Connor, he did but I would like to clear up one thing that Mr. Moore stated.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: One...

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Well I just I hope you will address that because if he actually did something but it was somehow inadequate assistance, then perhaps Strickland is the test.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: But if...

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: he did absolutely nothing, then we have to wrestle with whether you divide it from, you know, sentencing phase from guilt innocence phase, and so forth.

turn.speaker: robert_l_hutton
turn.label: Mr. Robert L. Hutton
turn.text: Justice O'Connor, Mr. Dice did make an opening statement, but in that opening statement, he also told the jury that he had a right to put on evidence at the penalty phase and had a right to make a closing argument in the penalty phase.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: And it's really bad performance, you can argue, having especially having made that statement, not to do it.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: But But...

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: I don't think that it proves that he wasn't there.

turn.speaker: robert_l_hutton
turn.label: Mr. Robert L. Hutton
turn.text: Justice Scalia, the problem in this case and the reason there's a total abdication of advocacy is because after the ca- State made a case for death, after the State put on proof of aggravating circumstances and then argued to the jury that the law required the jury to put Mr. Cone to death, there was silence.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Well, he had he had asked questions on cross examination, and it may be that he was satisfied that the State hadn't shown much.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: He wasn't...

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: going to give them an opportunity to have some stem winder and and and this is not standard but it is is it is not an unknown strategy.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: It was a...

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: very effective strategy for that particular advocate.

turn.speaker: robert_l_hutton
turn.label: Mr. Robert L. Hutton
turn.text: Justice Kennedy, the only role of an advocate in the penalty phase of a capital trial is to make a case for life.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Or it implies to the jury that the State has shown nothing.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: That's...

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: a completely permissible inference, and counsel does that has been known to do that.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: W- We have counsel up here sometimes who say I I waive rebuttal.

turn.speaker: robert_l_hutton
turn.label: Mr. Robert L. Hutton
turn.text: Justice Scalia, if a member of the Court asked a question of counsel and counsel stood silent, the necessary implication of that is I have no good reply for that question.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Mr.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: Hutton, this was a very short proceeding.

turn.speaker: robert_l_hutton
turn.label: Mr. Robert L. Hutton
turn.text: Yes,

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: It shows that Mr. Dice did did something.

turn.speaker: robert_l_hutton
turn.label: Mr. Robert L. Hutton
turn.text: Well, Your Honor, I would submit we know that Mr. Dice was suffering from mental illness at the time he testified.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: I'm asking you about those words.

turn.speaker: robert_l_hutton
turn.label: Mr. Robert L. Hutton
turn.text: Y- Your Honor, I think e- I would submit that that's more of a statement of grandiosity, but even if it was a plea for mercy, our position is that after the opening statements, nothing happened to make a case for life.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: W- Why W- Th- I'd like you to go into that.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: exactly the...

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: same reaction as Justice Ginsburg.

turn.speaker: robert_l_hutton
turn.label: Mr. Robert L. Hutton
turn.text: Justice Breyer, there there're two points in response.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: In other words,

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: you're saying on that part...

turn.speaker: robert_l_hutton
turn.label: Mr. Robert L. Hutton
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: when Paul Freund sometimes has said, a lawyer in this Court who sits down saying nothing makes not just a good argument, but a perfect argument.

turn.speaker: robert_l_hutton
turn.label: Mr. Robert L. Hutton
turn.text: Okay.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: My reading this transcript led me to think maybe it wasn't the perfect response, but it was a good one, because in the introductory statement I'll repeat myself he made all his arguments.

turn.speaker: robert_l_hutton
turn.label: Mr. Robert L. Hutton
turn.text: Number one, Your Honor, it's not just the failure to make a statement.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: conviction...

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: me.

turn.speaker: robert_l_hutton
turn.label: Mr. Robert L. Hutton
turn.text: No, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: penalty phase.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: allude to that evidence?

turn.speaker: robert_l_hutton
turn.label: Mr. Robert L. Hutton
turn.text: No, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: mitigating ev-

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: but surely the jury would assume that they could consider it if he referred to it.

turn.speaker: robert_l_hutton
turn.label: Mr. Robert L. Hutton
turn.text: Your Honor, for a jury who's just rejected an insanity defense and this will Justice Scalia, this plays into the second point, too.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: pro-

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: He says the defense has put on proof of those mitigating circumstances during its case.

turn.speaker: robert_l_hutton
turn.label: Mr. Robert L. Hutton
turn.text: Justice Breyer, ther- the problem with that evidence was that the post conviction court made a finding there was prosecutorial misconduct where the prosecution improperly argued that the jury should not believe the evidence with respect to drug usage.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: phase.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: you go to I don't want you to lose two, though.

turn.speaker: robert_l_hutton
turn.label: Mr. Robert L. Hutton
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Because I want to elicit from you what your response is.

turn.speaker: robert_l_hutton
turn.label: Mr. Robert L. Hutton
turn.text: Okay.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Well I, you know, I have trouble with that because I don't think the State put on very much, and if I'm sitting waiting for this closing argument, I know what I'm going to hear.

turn.speaker: robert_l_hutton
turn.label: Mr. Robert L. Hutton
turn.text: Hm.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: But then the prosecutor says, this man with a Bronze Star killed a helpless, innocent couple.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: got me...

turn.speaker: robert_l_hutton
turn.label: Mr. Robert L. Hutton
turn.text: But Justice Kennedy, at least then the jury has something to weigh.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: All right.

turn.speaker: robert_l_hutton
turn.label: Mr. Robert L. Hutton
turn.text: No, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: No.

turn.speaker: robert_l_hutton
turn.label: Mr. Robert L. Hutton
turn.text: Justice Breyer, put another way, the question the Court is asking is whether or not a lawyer can strategically decide to abandon advocacy.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: ah- All he has...

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: abandoned...

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: is his closing statement.

turn.speaker: robert_l_hutton
turn.label: Mr. Robert L. Hutton
turn.text: No, Justice Breyer.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: No, but Mr. Hutton, the problem that I think we're all having with your argument i- is is illustrated by the the colloquy that keeps going on.

turn.speaker: robert_l_hutton
turn.label: Mr. Robert L. Hutton
turn.text: Justice Souter, it's our position that, in essence, the lawyer's judgments are irrelevant to a Cronic analysis, that Cronic looks at the...

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: structure of...

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: the whole problem, because if we were analyzing it under Strickland, we would have a different sort of inquiry, and maybe it fits better here.

turn.speaker: robert_l_hutton
turn.label: Mr. Robert L. Hutton
turn.text: No, Justice...

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: O'Connor.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: would happen then? And how should we address it with these two questions? Do we deal with twenty-two fifty-four first as a threshold question?

turn.speaker: robert_l_hutton
turn.label: Mr. Robert L. Hutton
turn.text: Justice O'Connor, if I could take both of your questions in the order you presented them.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: You know I I...

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: I-

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: It's h- It puts you in a bad position for me to ask you this, but just assume, if you would for a minute, that we think Strickland applies.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: your client?

turn.speaker: robert_l_hutton
turn.label: Mr. Robert L. Hutton
turn.text: Justice O'Connor, the if Strickland did apply, the twenty-two fifty-four D question could not be resolved until first the procedural default issues and the failure to afford an evidentiary hearing questions are resolved by the Sixth Circuit.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: we not decide the toi- the preju- the Strickland question here?

turn.speaker: robert_l_hutton
turn.label: Mr. Robert L. Hutton
turn.text: Okay.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: What what were those...

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Were these questions dealing with the guilt phase or the penalty phase?

turn.speaker: robert_l_hutton
turn.label: Mr. Robert L. Hutton
turn.text: Your Honor, these are all questions that apply to application of Sixth Amendment, the failure to develop...

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: evidence...

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: I I asked you a specific question.

turn.speaker: robert_l_hutton
turn.label: Mr. Robert L. Hutton
turn.text: With respect to the penalty phase specifically, Chief Justice Rehnquist, with respect to developing proof as to deficient performance, why the findings of fact should not be trusted because ment-

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: me- mis-

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: didn't the Sixth Circuit reject your claim about the guilt phase?

turn.speaker: robert_l_hutton
turn.label: Mr. Robert L. Hutton
turn.text: e- No Your what they rejected, there was a- an issue of waiver of certain claims, not the Sixth Amendment claims, but other claims that was denied by the district court, and the Sixth Circuit found that those issues were waived.

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: Can you can you point to me where in the Sixth Circuit opinion I thought in their opinion they rejected your claim insofar as the guilt phase.

turn.speaker: robert_l_hutton
turn.label: Mr. Robert L. Hutton
turn.text: No, Justice Ginsburg.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Excuse m- I I I don't I don't really understand.

turn.speaker: robert_l_hutton
turn.label: Mr. Robert L. Hutton
turn.text: Because...

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: I don't understand why we can't just just look at the evidence that was available and and decide the the Strickland question then.

turn.speaker: robert_l_hutton
turn.label: Mr. Robert L. Hutton
turn.text: Justice Scalia, that fits right into this court's decision with Michael Williams versus Taylor.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Justice...

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: any indiction here as to whose fault it was?

turn.speaker: robert_l_hutton
turn.label: Mr. Robert L. Hutton
turn.text: We Your Honor, there's several different issues, Justice Souter.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: under Michael Williams versus...

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: facts is it what facts is it are are they that that you sought to develop?

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Ch- Chief...

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: bearing on the ineffective assistance claim?

turn.speaker: robert_l_hutton
turn.label: Mr. Robert L. Hutton
turn.text: Chief Justice, there's several facts, starting with the deficient performance aspect.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: law f-

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: W- W- Why doe- how does that bear on whether or not the State court's finding of against you on the Strickland claim was unreasonable?

turn.speaker: robert_l_hutton
turn.label: Mr. Robert L. Hutton
turn.text: Because, Chief Justice, many of the findings by the State court relied on the testimony of John Dice, and just like under the old Townsend versus Sain...

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: and...

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Townsend against Sain is pretty well gone.

turn.speaker: robert_l_hutton
turn.label: Mr. Robert L. Hutton
turn.text: No, Your Honor, but it also comes into Michael Williams versus Taylor, this Court's two thousand term two th- year two thousand opinion, where if it's not if we didn't fail to develop facts in in State court that are relevant, we can develop them in Federal court.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: What is what is the particular thing, though, because I mean, you've mentioned three times now that he has some mental problem that led him to commit suicide.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: gather that must have been at least four or five years after these events.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: It was a-

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: testified at the hearing in nineteen eighty-six.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: Now, I've seen many bad cases of bad representation in death cases that I think is terrible.

turn.speaker: robert_l_hutton
turn.label: Mr. Robert L. Hutton
turn.text: e- Justice Breyer, with respect to your first question, we're raising the fact that he committed suicide after the post conviction testimony so that that imp- that qu-

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: raises...

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: does not suggest that four or five years earlier it might suggest a cause of bad representation, but it doesn't suggest there was the bad representation.

turn.speaker: robert_l_hutton
turn.label: Mr. Robert L. Hutton
turn.text: Justice Breyer, he failed to make a case for life.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: [Inaudible]

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: you with this? And I because I think we're all trying to get at the same thing.

turn.speaker: robert_l_hutton
turn.label: Mr. Robert L. Hutton
turn.text: With resp- Justice Souter, there're m- many cases for life that could have been made.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Number tw--

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: was there nothing in the military record that the lawyer might have been fearful about if he pursued that beyond where he did?

turn.speaker: robert_l_hutton
turn.label: Mr. Robert L. Hutton
turn.text: No, Justice Ginsburg.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: So...

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: just m- I've looked back at the opinion, and twice the Sixth Circuit says that they deny the they affirm the dismissal.

turn.speaker: robert_l_hutton
turn.label: Mr. Robert L. Hutton
turn.text: No, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: We di-

turn.speaker: ruth_bader_ginsburg
turn.label: Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg
turn.text: you t- you told me when I asked you, no, the Sixth Circuit didn't affirm with respect to the sentence of conviction.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: phase.

turn.speaker: robert_l_hutton
turn.label: Mr. Robert L. Hutton
turn.text: I'm sorry, Justice Ginsburg.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: petition.

turn.speaker: robert_l_hutton
turn.label: Mr. Robert L. Hutton
turn.text: Okay.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: phase...

turn.speaker: robert_l_hutton
turn.label: Mr. Robert L. Hutton
turn.text: of the capital...

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Mr.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Could I ask you one question following up on Justice Souter? He listed three things.

turn.speaker: robert_l_hutton
turn.label: Mr. Robert L. Hutton
turn.text: N- no, Your Your Honor, there were some references by Mr. Dice's testimony that he thought that the mother, Valeree Cone, did not make a good witness and that generally the family members he thought did not make a good witness.

turn.speaker: stephen_g_breyer
turn.label: Justice Stephen G. Breyer
turn.text: that come in during the dur- had that come in during the guilt stage?

turn.speaker: robert_l_hutton
turn.label: Mr. Robert L. Hutton
turn.text: Your Honor, vera- th- th- he at- when he tried to introduce evidence in the guilt phase, there were objections as to relevancy which were sustained by the court, because the court found that all that was relevant in the guilt phase was the issue of mental insanity.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: particular...

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: mother testify in the...

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: to send th- th- th- this conviction and sentence occurred in nineteen eighty-two.

turn.speaker: robert_l_hutton
turn.label: Mr. Robert L. Hutton
turn.text: Your Honor, first of a- this case was...

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: filed...

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: How old is is is Mr. Cone?

turn.speaker: robert_l_hutton
turn.label: Mr. Robert L. Hutton
turn.text: Mr. Cone was thirty-three in nineteen-eighty-two, so that would make him fifty...

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Yeah, well, fifty-thr- he may he may get a...

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: life sentence by default.

turn.speaker: robert_l_hutton
turn.label: Mr. Robert L. Hutton
turn.text: Justice Scalia, though the the the fact of the matter th- is, though, that Mr. Cone has been trying to develop these...

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: claims.

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: but when you go back to that, what is it that you that you say should have gone in as evidence at the sentencing phase that didn't? The Bronze Star.

turn.speaker: robert_l_hutton
turn.label: Mr. Robert L. Hutton
turn.text: Your Honor, that should've gone in.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Mr. Dice's...

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: What what about the other two that I mentioned, the the the death of the sister and the murder of of the the the the girlfriend? Should those things have gone in?

turn.speaker: robert_l_hutton
turn.label: Mr. Robert L. Hutton
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor, because they would...

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: portray par-

turn.speaker: david_h_souter
turn.label: Justice David H. Souter
turn.text: I'm pushing you because your time is running out.

turn.speaker: robert_l_hutton
turn.label: Mr. Robert L. Hutton
turn.text: Your Honor, those should've gone in, but more importantly, those should've been woven into an argument as to why the reasoned moral judgment a reasoned moral judgment called for this man not to be put to death.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Thank you.
